But the idea oi quasi-delict, which is open to the same objection, is further to be condemned as really unnecessary, as will appear from the cases by which it is exemplified (Blc iv. 5 inl), most of which are instanccs ol vicarious responsibility analogous to the liabilityin tort os a railway company or other employer for the wrong-doing or negligence ol its servants. lts existence is to be accounted for purely on historical grounds (see Hunter’s Roman Law p. xxxvi), and it is to be regretted that Justinian tolerated its survival The actual sources oi obligation in Roman law may more logically be arranged as follows: (1)Agreement‚ comprising the iour classes ol contracts, the so-called innominate contracts, and pacta vestita. (2) Quasi-contract, including tutela, cura, negotiorum gestio, joint inheritance, joint ownership not arising ex contractu, litis contestatio, and perhaps the unjust enrichment osone man at the cost oi another (cf. The idea os agreement (conventio or pactio) underlies that of con· tractus: ‘et est pactio duorum pluriumve in idem placitum consensus' Dig. 2. 14 1. 2. lts analysis into the elements of offeror proposal and acceptance is the work rather of general jurisprudence than of a particular system, which has been done once ior all by Savigny, Oblig. ξ 52, System iii. §§ 140, ¹4¹: cl. Polloclr's Principles ol Contract, chap. i. Pactio then is the genus oi which contractus is the species: the differentia lies in the circumstance that to certain pacta or pactiones a civilis obligatio was annexed by the older Roman civil law in virtue either of their nature, or of their being attended by some other fact besides the mere fact of agreement. That, through which a pactum is also a contract, is usually called its causa civilis, and of such causae civiles there are four, viz. (1) res, delivery of ownership, possession or detention ot' an object by the creditor, whence the four Real Contracts. (2) The expression of the agreement in a certain verbal form (obligatio verborum), that oi question and answer (stipulatio) being regarded as the verbal contract par excellence.
